channel.title: NYT > World

item.title: Afghans Vote in Strong Numbers Despite Dangers
item.description: The election will mark the first time Afghans have changed their leader at the polls in modern history as Hamid Karzai’s dozen years in power end.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Hamid Karzai cast his vote at a local polling station in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Saturday.

item.title: World Briefing: Uganda: Police Raid U.S.-Financed Health Project
item.description: Police officers raided the offices of an American-financed project that offers services to AIDS patients, a government spokesman said Friday, in what appeared to be the first public action to enforce a new anti-homosexuality law.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: At War Blog: We Were Just Laughing: Days With Anja Niedringhaus and Kathy Gannon
item.description: A reporter who was recently with Anja Niedringhaus and Kathy Gannon of The Associated Press, longtime fellow chroniclers of events in Afghanistan, reflects on the attack on them and the changing environment in the country.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:description: The photographer Anja Niedringhaus at a swimming event at the 2004 Olympic Games in Athens.

item.title: Judge Dismisses Suit Against Administration Officials Over Drone Strikes
item.description: A federal judge ruled that courts should hesitate before holding a government official personally responsible for violating a citizen’s rights in the context of a wartime action.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: French Push U.N. to Seek War Crimes Case in Syria
item.description: The French have taken the first steps toward a Security Council referral of Syrians suspected of war crimes to the International Criminal Court.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Covering Afghan Vote, Until Shot by an Ally
item.description: Anja Niedringhaus, a Pulitzer Prize-winning photographer for The Associated Press, was attacked in eastern Afghanistan as she traveled to cover preparations for the presidential vote.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG and FAROOQ JAN MANGAL

item.title: U.S. to Reassess Status of Talks on Middle East
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry said he was flying home to Washington to meet with President Obama to reassess the peace negotiations, and whether there is a path forward.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and MARK LANDLER

item.title: Curtis Bill Pepper, Reporter and Traveler, Is Dead at 96
item.description: Mr. Pepper, a prolific journalist and author, excelled at finding anecdotes that revealed greater truths about his subjects.
item.dc:creator: By DENNIS HEVESI

item.title: U.S. Eyes Afghan Vote, Seeking Amenable Ally
item.description: Obama administration officials will closely watch this weekend’s election in Afghanistan, hoping that a successor to President Hamid Karzai will allow international troops to remain on the ground.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Election workers in Kabul prepared ballots for shipment ahead of Saturday’s presidential vote.

item.title: Lingering Hope vs. Onset of Grief Over Lost Flight
item.description: Two sons of passengers on Flight 370 have chosen different ways to cope: One holds vigil with other passengers’ relatives, while the other is assuming the worst.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Relatives of Chinese passengers on the missing Malaysia Airlines plane prayed in Beijing on Friday. It has been four weeks since the flight disappeared.

item.title: World Briefing: Kosovo: European Union Plans War Crimes Tribunal
item.description: The European Union plans to set up an international tribunal focusing exclusively on crimes believed to have been committed by Kosovo’s ethnic Albanian rebels during their war with Serbia, officials said.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Indonesia: Payment Spares Maid in Saudi Arabia
item.description: Indonesia has agreed to pay $1.8 million to prevent one of its citizens from being executed in Saudi Arabia, just days before she was to be beheaded for killing her employer.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Belgium: European Workers Demonstrate for Jobs
item.description: Protesters from across Europe clashed with the police in Brussels on Friday at a demonstration against high unemployment and austerity measures in Europe.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Iran: Border Guards Released by Pakistani Militants
item.description: Four of five Iranian border guards seized by Pakistani militants along the volatile Iran-Pakistan frontier two months ago have been released, Iran state media reported Friday.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Affluent Wine Buyers in Asia Find Their Confidence
item.description: An adventurous and increasingly educated crowd is fueling a boom in fine wines in China and elsewhere in Asia, though prices have come down.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By BETTINA WASSENER
item.media:credit: Dean C.K. Cox for The New York Times
item.media:description: A sommelier at the InterContinental Hotel in Hong Kong dusts off wine bottles on display.

item.title: News Analysis: A Peace Process in Which Process Has Come to Outweigh Peace
item.description: All three parties have vested interests in the Middle East peace process, leading analysts to say the current Kerry-led negotiations are inhibiting a final reckoning.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: The Lede: Iran’s Reformers Include More Than One Former Hostage-Taker
item.description: Hostage-takers who became leading reformers in Iran include the man who devised the plan to seize the United States Embassy in Tehran in 1979 and the woman who explained the group’s demands to foreign reporters.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A recent image of Hamid Aboutalebi from Iran's Khabar Online.

item.title: Syria Ships Out More Chemicals After a 2-Week Lapse
item.description: The delay raised questions about whether Syria can meet an extended deadline of April 27 to export its chemical weapons arsenal for destruction.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: 3 in India Sentenced to Death for 2 Rapes
item.description: The three men were sentenced under the strict provisions of a new law in India that has caused unease even among some women’s advocates.
item.dc:creator: By MANSI CHOKSI and GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: Salim Ansari was taken on Friday into a Mumbai court, where he and two other men were sentenced for rape under strict new provisions that resulted from a series of high-profile cases.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: April 4
item.description: India’s Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle, carrying a navigation satellite, blasted off from the spaceport in Sriharikota, Andhra Pradesh.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A contrail left behind as India's Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle, carrying a navigation satellite, lifted off from the Satish Dhawan Space Centre in Sriharikota, Andhra Pradesh.

item.title: India Ink: What They Said: Death Penalty Imposed in Mumbai Gang Rapes
item.description: The death sentences handed down to three men convicted of raping two women last year have drawn a range of reactions, from jubilation to skepticism.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR

item.title: World Briefing: Russia: 4 Soldiers Killed in Chechnya
item.description: Four Russian servicemen were killed and seven were wounded when a bomb hit their vehicle in the North Caucasus republic of Chechnya, Russia’s Interior Ministry said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: As Strike Winds Down, Lufthansa Plans a Return to Nearly Normal Service
item.description: The airline said most flights would operate this weekend, after a three-day strike, although there was no sign the company and the pilots were closer to resolving their dispute.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Leftward Shift by Conservative Cleric Leaves Saudis Perplexed
item.description: Salman al-Awda, who won fame for his hard-line views, speaks up for democracy and amplifies his voice with social media.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT F. WORTH
item.media:description: Salman al-Awda has become a promoter of democracy and tolerance.

item.title: George Bush’s Portrait Exhibition Opens in Dallas
item.description: The world’s most distinctive gallery of world leaders, the work of George W. Bush, who took up painting after he left office, opens in Dallas on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:credit: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times
item.media:description: Portraits of (clockwise from bottom left) former President Nicolas Sarkozy of France, Prime Minister Stephen Harper of Canada, the crown prince of Abu Dhabi, Mohammed bin Zayed, and the former president of South Korea, Lee Myung-bak. All were painted by former President George W. Bush.
